{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3314110,"name":"Nathaniel","username":"NathanielH","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/b77776/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-21T01:45:42.911Z","cooked":"

We are experiencing incredibly inconsistent behavior when mapping buttons to set motor speeds (For both Xbox and Flight Stick).

We are using the REV MAXswerve template. We have 2 motors relevant to this issue: our intake motors and our shooting motors (We are using NEOs and SparkMAXs) To intake, we slowly move both of these in order to load a game piece. To shoot, we move only the shooter wheels, but faster.

We created an IntakeCommand and a ShooterCommand. Originally the code to map those buttons was separated into its individual commands; for some reason, more buttons worked when moved to ShooterCommand. Both commands are made and scheduled the exact same way, which makes this problem confusing.

Additionally, the motors that actually worked changed depending on whether we used the Xbox Controller or the Flight Stick. Sometimes a motor would shift slightly and then stop, sometimes it would outright not move.

We know this is not an electrical issue because we’ve mapped different buttons for the intake and the shooting, and the shooter wheels work fine sometimes when moving slower in order to intake; then, we find that another button that moves them in the opposite direction to shoot does not move them. We’ve also checked that the buttons are being registered on the DriverStation.

This is our code for our intake:

//Spins intake wheels and flywheels (loads note)
if (RobotContainer.xboxController.getRightBumper()) {
IntakeSubsystem.intakeMotor.set(0.5);
ShooterSubsystem.shooterWheels.set(0.3);
}
// Reverses intake wheels and flywheels (unlaods note)
else if (RobotContainer.xboxController.getLeftBumper()){
IntakeSubsystem.intakeMotor.set(-0.5);
ShooterSubsystem.shooterWheels.set(-0.3);
}
// Stops intake and flywheels
else {
IntakeSubsystem.intakeMotor.set(0);
ShooterSubsystem.shooterWheels.set(0);
}

Currently, this code does not work.

do you have a link to the full code? its a little hard to troubleshoot with just a snippit

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-02-21T02:20:25.822Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":22.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":455512,"topic_slug":"inconsistent-button-behavior","display_username":"Nick Anastasoff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57441,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/inconsistent-button-behavior/455512/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3314145,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-21T02:37:09.152Z","cooked":"

Have you considered using the WPI button functions to schedule commands on the rising and falling edges, instead of polling the button States and commanding the motors continuously?

The next layer after that would be to use the buttons to schedule commands which require the subsystem, which then handles your conflicting resources for you.

You are seeing a resource conflict.

This code snippet sends new motor settings every periodic loop. So, even if you schedule and run a shoot command next to it, the shoot command motorSet(x) will immediately get overwritten by the null case motorSet(0) from this “if” tree on the next periodic loop.

If you rewrite these statements to use commands that require the intake and shooter motors, then when you trigger a shooter command that also requires the shooter motor, the command scheduler will gracefully resolve the conflict.

I don’t have access to the code right now, but I guarantee you that is the issue. Thank you so much, I’ll let you know if it works

From the code sent, I’d infer that they aren’t using command-based.
Command-based does solve a lot of problems like this, but transitioning to command-based isn’t something I’d recommend to do in the middle of a season.

Starlight220:

I’d infer that they aren’t using command-based.

That’s a good point, even though they called what they’re doing a capital-C Command, the code snippet looks like iterative loops in a periodic function.

I hope the rising edge and falling edge tools are available in the base timedRobot/iterativeRobot classes, they’ll make it much easier for OP to solve this even if they don’t have real Commands.
